translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The One Who Has Broken Through Before
“How does one see, how does one conduct oneself,
to be called peaceful?
Please tell me this, Gotama,
when asked, O supreme human.”
“Free from craving before the break,
(so said the Blessed One)
Depended on the past;
In the middle, he is not to be reckoned,

analyzed: tassa natthi purakkhata  akkodhanaḥ asantāsī  a vikatthī a kukkucaḥ
translated: he has no future.🔽Not angry, not resentful,🔽not deceitful, not a hypocrite;
A speaker of Dhamma, not restless,
he is indeed a sage who guards speech.
Not longing for the future,
not grieving over the past;
Seeing seclusion in contacts,

original: diṭṭhīsu ca na nīyati.🔽Patilīno akuhako,🔽apihālu amaccharī;
analyzed: diṭṭhīsu ca na  pati līnaḥ a kuhakaḥ  apihālu amaccharī
translated: he is not led astray by views.🔽Inclined, not deceitful,🔽not greedy, not stingy;
Not overbearing, not contemptuous,

analyzed: pesuṇeyye ca naḥ yutaḥ  sātiyesu anassāvī
translated: not entangled in slander.🔽Not envious, not domineering,
not attached to gain;
Gentle and eloquent,
he is not faithless, not dispassionate.
Not training out of desire for gain,
not angry at lack of gain;
Not opposing craving,
he does not pursue tastes.
Always equanimous, mindful,
he does not consider the world equal to himself;
He is not contemptible or low,
he has no arrogance.
He who has no dependence,
knowing the Dhamma, independent;
For the sake of existence or non-existence,
for whom craving does not exist.

analyzed: tam brūmi upasantā iti  kāmesu anapekkhina
translated: I call him peaceful,🔽who is not concerned with sensual pleasures;
His fetters do not exist,
he has crossed over the flood.

original: Na tassa puttā pasavo,🔽Khettaṁ vatthuñca vijjati;
analyzed: na tassa puttā pasavaḥ  khettam vatthuñca vijjati
translated: He has no children or cattle,🔽no field or land exists for him;
The self or the selfless,

original: Na tasmiṁ upalabbhati.🔽Yena naṁ vajjuṁ puthujjanā,
analyzed: na tasmin upalabbhati  yena nam vajjum puthujjanā
translated: is not found in him.🔽By which the world would blame him,
whether ordinary people, ascetics or brahmins;
That is not his fault,
therefore he does not go to extremes in views.
Free from anger, not envious,
the sage does not speak of heights;
Not in the low or the high,
he goes through the aeon as one not bound.
For whom there is nothing of his own in the world,
and he does not grieve over what is not;
and he does not go to extremes in regards to qualities,

analyzed: sa ve santo ti vuccati iti 🔽purābheda suttam dasama
translated: he is said to be peaceful.”🔽The Sutta on the Former Dispute is the tenth.
